pros: A good environment for an introvert who enjoys learning new systems from a 300 page slideshow, and does not mind the ambiguity of indirect non specific answers to most questions regarding process. A fire safe work space for the employee that agrees that keeping your door shut at all times and management also having their door shut at all times is the best way to prevent the spread of possible fire. The 401K program is above average and medical imaging has been cheap in the past for employees. There is a long list of inexpensive OTC medications that are available for purchase at the CHI pharmacy. CHI pharmacists and techs are the best I've ever met.
cons: Leadership is unqualified, unknowledgeable, and may not have any clinical experience in the department they run or any medical experience at all. This is true at all levels of leadership. To save a quick dime, changes that impact significant long term revenue is sacrificed. Practitioners pay the price for this through direct aggression/blame and through vile microaggressions. A person with no knowledge of your field will decide if your performance warrants a merit increase. At my last review I was told "This review does not reflect the quality of your work." Equal respect for female providers does not exist. If you are a female provider desperate for a job, befriend a male coworker and proceed with 1950's protocols for getting things done.

Many ways to grow within the hospital. You get to know people from other departments and can move around pretty easily if you want.
cons:
A lot of politics and people that are so unhappy at their job. You hear constant complaining, but people will stay for years. Bringing overall moral of the department down.

 They keep lazy people that do not work or do bare minimum because the union will fight to keep all it's employees.

Very strict time limits (understandably) on completing a task. And depending on who your lead for the day is they will either help you sink or swim.

Alot of drama, backstabbing, and cliches. It's like highschool in a hospital environment.

Always short staffed.

The job can be hard, and the things you deal with on the daily (biohazards/death/devastated family members etc..) can be tough. There is always something going on.

review_title: A fair place to work most of the time
job_title: Lead Childcare Teacher in Chattanooga, TN
pros: Decent pay and benefits to start. Lots of benefits for the health and safety of the employees.....healthy living advice and guidance and ways to earn side cash for signing up to participate in healthy lifestyle changes and learn by reading articles and studies. Decent retirement plan that the company does match what you put in for a certain amount of time.
cons:
Raises are a joke....at least for my department...I don't think clinical gets shafted as much. I'm thankful that I get paid better than many childcare professionals especially in my area in the south. But, with Covid causing so much hardship to those of us who work as essential employees, the clinical personnel were compensated greatly but associates in other areas who were bombarded with tons of extra work and no help because no one wants to work. Regardless of all our extra stress we were not given any extra compensation or help at all. I don't necessarily think this was intentional?? Maybe we just kind of got forgotten in all the chaos? Obviously the hospital clinical staff was under the most stress and hardship. I don't downplay that. However, we have been understaffed and overcome with more children to care for while the parents of children in our state received free childcare for almost 2 years. A little more help with more staff or better wage increases as companies across the globe are paying employees more per hour would've been greatly appreciated. We received nothing of the sort. And as prices for everything increase daily we are left with the same little .25-.40 cent raise as always. Barely enough to cover the cost of our company insurance that increases most every year. We're working ourselves ragged and the cost of living keeps sky rocketing and financially its a strain when you're not compensated and raised up like other workers.
I realize that I sound negative and I don't mean to be. I do appreciate what the company does and it is not a horrible place to work. As stated above I am thankful that my company pays better for my job position than many many others. Simply put we've been worked almost into exhaustion these last couple years and it seems like we've been overlooked. My health and well being and my bank account could use a little boost like the other staff at the hospital has received.

review_title: Horrible Management + Toxic Environment = Bad Morale;
pros: I cannot think of one positive aspect in regards to working at CHI St. Luke’s- Baylor St. Luke’s Medical Center.
cons:
Supervisors and other management are absolutely horrible! They do not care about their employees as anything other than instruments for making the hospital money. They purposely understaff, but refuse to reduce the patient volume to match the limited number of staff simply to maximize their profits. Departments are poorly organized, yet management is excessively strict in regards to employee policies. They even refuse to provide adequate equipment and work supplies. The atmosphere is toxic and the overall morale is pathetic. There is no such thing as “teamwork” as every employee is only out for his/her self. There is usually one person, possibly two in every department who does the majority of the work while the rest of the staff only pretend to be busy. Benefits are awful and employees are basically restricted to using only Baylor doctors, otherwise insurance will not pay anything. 
If you interview with CHI St. Luke’s - Baylor St. Luke’s Medical Center, they will promise you the moon to get you hired. But once you’re there, they do not reliever on any of their promises. Beware of this place! It literally is just a massive “sweat shop” masquerading as (in their own ridiculously egocentric words) a “World Class Health are Organization.”
Nothing could be farther from the truth. Avoid this place at all costs!

pros:
1. The benefits are great, you have several choices of healthcare plans.
2. Cost of living in Bryan / College Station isn't that bad.
cons:
1. If you are looking for an EMS job, look elsewhere.
2. The personnel are worked to death, they need to replace their equipment, and build new station; but CHI won't provide EMS the money.
3. I was told they had a "robust training and CME program".  In fact they have an average orientation, and no CME program to speak of.
4. I was told that their "hold over days" are used to cover last minute calls outs that no one will cover, and that you rarely get "held over".  The truth is they use the "hold over days" to cover open shifts, vacation days, events, and vacant positions so you are held over most of your "hold over days".  Imagine working 48 hour straight with little to no sleep, having 24 hours off then back for a 24 hour shift. 
5. I was told upon clearing  orientation I would get a 5% pay raise, I got a 2.5% pay raise.
6. You are expected to be a technician not a clinician. Don't expect to use individual judgement based on training, experience and education; they want blind obedience to a protocol, but in their defense, that is EMS now days.

review_title: STAY AWAY! ... at least from the APSC
pros: A few good leaders and some really great people to work with.
cons:
Unfortunately, there are a lot of cons with the APSC.  I honestly feel that the following are the most unforgiving:
   
 * Our director decided, about 6-months ago, to change the attendance policy to not allow any forgiveness, even if we call in the previous day. No matter what we will get an occurrence. Instead of holding the employees that were having attendance problems accountable you brought it down on everyone and wiped the slate clean of occurrences for the abusers. 
    * Shortly after that, all of us employees receive an email threatening our jobs (on performance) if any employee made 3 mistakes in the same month. But it appears as though it was an empty threat as the APSC has seen no change with the amount of errors. 
    * Our director still shows her inability to communicate to her department by stating 4-weeks ago that we would all be told the plan for replacing a supervisor fired as an escape goat for her and her Interim manager's  incompetencies.

review_title: Disaster if you work in IT
pros: My Co-workers are great. 23 days of PTO
cons:
Mandatory that 6 of those PTO days are taken at Christmas for 2nd year in a row.

IT was outsourced to India 2 years ago and has been in a full on nose dive ever since.  If you are thinking of applying for an IT position think long and hard. Processes that used to take days now take months because outsourced staff is incompetent. Physicians are screaming because outsourced helpdesk staff is impossible to understand and can't resolve issues.  Two minute calls to the helpdesk now take 20. They are now bringing a clinical help desk onshore because it has gotten so ridiculous. Infrastructure is completely unstable. We now have daily 7:30am calls to discuss outages because they are so frequent. Networks going down all the time, exchange issues weekly, servers being rebooted in the middle of the day with no notice. In addition to doing the jobs we have always done we now also have the job of babysitting our outsourced partners to ensure they aren't breaking our applications and our hardware. Full time job on its own.  Have spent roughly 20 hours over the past 2 weeks fixing things they broke.  Oh how we miss having technical staff who knew what the heck they were doing! 

This place was great to work for prior to outsourcing.  Until they bring IT tech services back in-house, run away.

pros: I have worked for CHI Franciscan for over 14 years.  When I think about what attracted me to Franciscan initially - it was their values and their mission.  What I wondered before I started was if those were just statements on paper or if the organization really stood by their values and mission and it was demonstrated by their workforce - especially their leaders.  What I have found over the years is that they do!  Our organization attracts people who have similar values and a passion for our mission - to be the BEST healthcare organization and to serve our patients no matter what.  I experience this passion every day in my interactions with leaders and front line employees.  I am inspired by the dedication of everyone who works here from those who do hands on patient care to those who ensure our facility is clean and safe.  While I have had some tough days at work, we all do, when I think about what brings me to work every day it is simple.  I am proud of the work I do and the difference I make every day and being a part of something so important that touches so many lives.  Come make a difference with us!

review_title: Great work/life balance, but little opportunity for advancement
pros: Work/life balance is great (dependant on team), and the PTO package cannot be beat (23 days plus 7 paid holidays)  CHI's "core values" are sound as long as the team practices them - reverance, integrity, compassion, excellence.  The Denver offices are in a great location in South Denver, far enough away from the Tech Center that traffic is avoided, but close enough to nice suburbs (Parker, Highlands Ranch, Castle Rock). For the most part, managers are very flexible with schedule and telecommuting is allowed on a consistent basis, some teams can work from home up to two days per week.
cons: Leadership is lacking and too much weight is placed on the analysis of consulting firms who give recommendations for cost cutting measures (several rounds of "restruturing", aka "layoffs") after being paid millions of dollars.  There is very little opportunity for advancement, and HR does not have career paths for the staff, although they say they are working on them.  There is also no formal training structure, so it is left to the individual teams to train their staff and management, but with budget cuts, training is always first to go.  For a non-profit organization, the company is very political.  There is no retirement contribution match, but there is a pension for anyone who can last 5 years.  Raises are equal to cost of living, for those who receive them.

pros: The people are genuinely nice, but that isn't enough to keep quality employees.  I think leaders want to be good leaders, but they don't know how.
cons: Definitely not high caliber personnel - don't consider CHI if you're looking for an A-level team.  Leadership doesn't understand how to talk to or work with employees, and everything is disjointed because people at all levels on every team work in silos.  There is a lot of talk about the core values, but leaders don't embody them, so it feels like they're lying every time they speak.  The work here isn't challenging - what is challenging is getting decisions made and executed.  The only focus is on cost savings which is usually at the expense of employees - you don't ever see leaders rolling up their sleeves and making sacrifices for the greater good.  This place has changed a lot in the 4 years I've been here, and all of the quality people are leaving for other jobs.

review_title: Some great aspects, most of the management is incompetent
pros: It's nice to work for a healthcare organization where you feel like you're helping people (or supporting the people that help people). cons: Management at most levels is incompetent.  There is a total lack of vision and reliance on consultants to get anything done.  Most managers are in a CYA mode.  There are a ton - I mean a TON - of meetings, sometimes just to figure out when another meeting could be scheduled.  Hospitals function independently, so everyone has their own processes and procedures.  RICE (Reverence, Integrity, Compassion, Excellence) values are constantly stressed, but management ignores them as soon as they feel like they can save a dollar.

pros: Pay, time off, works with scheduling

review_title: A mixed bag of priorities which really makes you think about yours.
pros: Actually seems to live its values in some ways and take care of its employees in some cases, which, sad as this is, is exceedingly rare in this day this golden age of corporate hypocrisy (which they have their own share of, unfortunately). Decent medical benefits and really good PTO  and retirement benefits.
cons: Mass confusion in the OneCare Project--cost overruns, over-reliance on contractors, poor central control, and even poorer choices to sacrifice internal IT infrastructure to pay for the mistakes of the implementation project leadership. Also, they don't cover birth control in their health plan, which is discriminatory and dogmatic for all of its consistency with their core values.

review_title: Losing good talent due to disjointed leadership and poor people management
pros: Work load is light and predictable. Pretty much a 9-5 company.
cons: Bonus is low or non-existent because the organization is losing money in most markets. Despite what they tell you when you join. Salaries do not increase much beyond joining. Very poor people management. Either too passive or too aggressive. Mixed messages from leadership means no one really knows where they stand from day to day. Despite claiming to be on the cutting edge of health care reform, they are in fact very behind. Too many ineffective, overpaid VPs and little opportunity for career progression. Health care benefits are average at best which is quite ironic. It takes ages to get anything done here as there is too much process and IT support is very poor. Too much time is wasted in meetings on 'reflections'. Overall a pretty toxic environment to work within and to be honest not worth it.

review_title: Not what the Sister's of St Francis had in mind.
pros: Nice view, clean bathrooms, pretty lobby
cons: Management's focus is on control, e.g. giving out prizes for doing what they want you to do.  What results is a lack of working for the sake of your work.  I'm a doctor.  I enjoy being a doctor.  I enjoy returning people to health and being part of their lives.  But, working at St Joe's, I get rewarded for seeing patients quickly and getting high scores in AIDET (a codified mechanical scripted way of interacting with others).  Making people healthier doesn't seem to be part of the equation.  Sincerity, doesn't seem to be part of the equation.  I usually get good reviews from patients because they see how much I truly enjoy working with them and seem to appreciate how much I like my work.  It sickens me, when a manager who has no clue why I would enjoy working with patients, hands me a certificate for two dollars complimenting me on being "so nice to the patients."

review_title: Great Tax and Legal Teams - Overall Best Employer of Career
pros:
-Good pay and benefits
-Collegial Atmosphere
-Challenging Work
-Individual Growth / Learning Opportunities
-CHI handles employee matters with compassion

I joined CHI over 9 years ago from public accounting.  While I considered opportunities with other healthcare systems, I joined CHI due to the size and complexity of the organization, expecting that those attributes would keep my work interesting. Indeed CHI has not been a disappointment.  The company has grown significantly over the last 9 years, and I have been fortunate to have been afforded tremendous opportunity to grow over that time.  I have experience with both the tax and legal teams, both high-performing groups within CHI.  These groups handle huge amounts of complex work with relatively modest staff.  The senior leader to whom these groups report is supportive, and appreciative of the work that these groups perform.

Overall, although the work hours are long, the pay is good, the work is challenging, CHI has given me great opportunities for growth and learning, and I have been supported by leadership.  I couldn't ask for a better employer.
cons:
CHI is going through challenging economic times
Heavy work load / long hours

pros: There isn't anything to say
cons: There are too many chiefs

pros: They do pay regular employees on time, though payment of contractors is not important to maangement.  I have watched a couple contractor friends of mine fight every week to get paid on time because their manager didn't approve their timecard on time.  When they went to HR they said there is nothing they can do.
cons: They make decisions based on no fact, they do not know how to run an IT dept.  They put people in management positions based on who is their friend, no experience to do the job but it is someones friend so they determine the path for many things, though they have no idea what they are talking about.  They make poor decisions, they treat people very poorly, especially since they aer supposed to be a religous orginization.  Overall they are a very terrible place to work, benefits are not good either, weird to work for a health care company that provides terrible healthcare for their employees.

review_title: Management above that of clinical managers is way out of touch
pros: Great co-workers and providers. Decent PTO and other benefits.
cons: Overworked clinical nursing staff to the point of dangerous burnout, particularly in the specialties with lots of office procedures and nurse visits. No time to handle administrative duties, i.e. prior auth for medications, managing all the medication inventories, let alone pt call-backs, diagnostic notifications, scheduling treatments. Loved my job when I started but with the advent of EPIC, decline quickly followed as well as poor morale. No work/life balance. So burned out, don't have energy to do anything after work. Weekends are spent catching up on sleep. The situation is dangerous to say the least. Imagine if the Sisters knew the true state of affairs, they'd be appalled. Couldn't take anymore so quit. The God I believe in wouldn't want this for me. Pay is subpar. The compensation department is failing the company.

pros: I was privileged to work with an excellent team of dynamic, very smart people. My pay was very fair. Work-life balance was honored and celebrated. I was proud to be part of a department in the national organization that was valued for its support of the local work that directly affects patient lives.
cons: Very poor decision-making among senior leadership is widely recognized both at the national and the local level. Just a few examples: Outsourcing IT to WiPro during the biggest and most important enterprise IT implementation in the company's history. Inability to decide whether to be an operating company or a holding company. Decisions that should be central left to indecisive local leadership. Mistrust from local facilities was profound, often justified, yet left unaddressed. Extensive, destructive layoffs driven by numbers rather than strategy.

review_title: Grade school level management/ very low morale
pros: Health insurance coverage was good to me and my family
cons: Revolving door, low pay, low morale, bad management, no breaks except a useless half hour lunch, no working from home, no laughing allowed, no talking allowed, you are to sit and work a set number accounts in your grey cubicles and if this is not done properly, you better look out.

review_title: New CEO is terrible, Morale an all-time LOW
pros: The residency program offered to new nurses is great. The people working on the units have great attitudes and a really good family vibe.
cons: HUGE cuts since the hiring of a new CEO that affect the frontline staff. They are cutting staffing levels, implementing flexible staffing, they fired all secretaries and are making nurses do that work, they are trying to implement total care meaning no more nursing assistants. They are being sued by the union over missed breaks. Patient care is heavy on all units, yet they are decreasing staff. They spend a lot of money on marketing, branding, and acquiring new assets, but they forget what makes these assets run - the people. Pay is below average. Many brand new nurses create great risk for patient care.

pros: Most of the other employees are very supportive and great to work with.  The doctors and MLPs treat the nurses with respect the overwhelming majority of the time. The hospital is well kept and up to date as far as technology goes. The pay is ok if you negotiate well up front as there are not many substantial raises.
cons: For a nonprofit organization, an exuberant amount of time is dedicated to increasing the bottom line and “productivity” of the unit at the expense of the wellbeing of staff. Administration makes many promises to staff to improve working conditions but their inability or unwillingness to follow through on what they say they will do always seems to be justified by for a multitude of reasons and are usually downplayed. There is little to no encouragement or incentive for nurses to further their education or expertise in their field. Short staffing issues are a major problem and are conveniently dismissed by leaders because according to their “staffing grids”, the units are fully staffed.

review_title: Good place to learn and work!
pros: They have many areas of interest for new nurses starting out and several great locations to choose from.  They treat their employees like family and most managers are very easy to work with about time off and special requests.  I will graduate next year and am looking forward to starting my first nursing job there!
cons: I worked for 18 months in renal dialyis as a dialysis technician and after my one year review I was told I met all the requirements for a $0.60 per hour raise.  I was happy to get the extra money but after two paychecks it never happened.  I called HR 4 times and talked to everyone, they all said they'd check into it and call me back but no one did.  I finally transferred out to a Nurse Technician in a different department.  I didn't want to fight it anymore.

pros: good people trying to make the best of it and hang on to their on-shore, FTE jobs. a bit pitiful to watch.
cons: It is openly discussed, behind closed doors, by long time CHI employee's that the CEO is taking the usual, under-the-table kick-backs from Wipro and Deloitte. Duuuuhhhh, that is exactly the way the business is run. CHI cuts huge payroll liabilities when they use technical non-u.s. citizens, and in fact, get subsidized by the u.s. government from doing so. Can you say, HB1? Deloitte management types, who bill $100 - $200/hour, are ensconced in their own private offices, where they plan and talk and plan some more into the weeeee hours. The out-sourced, onshore non-u.s. citizens are highly resented by FTE CHI employee's. Hence, the FTE'rs sabatoge projects. Budgets are not available to pay equipment suppliers, delaying project deadlines and successfully making everyone look bad. Except the CEO. He and his C-level buddies get their payoffs, you can be sure, and the off-shore Indian based staffers, get their bonuses. The MBO's suffer, while their IT systems are at risk of not performing thereby putting their patience lives at risk.

review_title: Lackluster at Best-Possibly A Sinking Ship
pros: Have met some great people as far as co-workers; a good place to see a lot of different medical cases/clinical situations; decent salary and benefits but not fantastic; well-regarded in the community
cons: Leadership is basically non-existent in the department I work in (you may not see your manager for weeks at a time and are likely to never get a reply to your email or phone message); incompetent and poor performing staff members are retained but their performance shortcomings are expected to be absorbed/compensated by the stronger performing staff members; organization talks about its values and integrity but that is just propaganda-what matters is that the upper management and physicians (who seem to walk on water at this place) get their whims and high salaries met while other staff members just squeak by; they expect full time employees to constantly pick up extra shifts and when people refuse they are told they are "not supporting their co-workers"

pros: Best reason to work there is to get experience in healthcare. And if you want to see what it's like to work in an organization that claims to be christian. Great experience finding out what work at a hypocritical organization is like. Honeymoon's over very quickly if you have good skills and experience. Great place if you have few skills have no experience sorting through smoke and mirrors. BELIEVE the negative reviews. The positive reviews must come from hospitals int he system and not national office.
cons: Witness the St. Peter Principle in action. It is just the peter principle with a supposedly christian theme pounded in constantly that the company adheres to reverence, integrity, compassion and excellence. Might be true for the care delivered. Certainly NOT TRUE on how employees are treated, especially in IT. Managers bully and get by with it. Good employees worked to the core and never rewarded. Only Director or above get more than cost of living, even though asked to take on more and more responsibility. And you will hear thank you constantly, but that's it, just the words.

pros: There aren't any Pros that I can think of.
cons: If you aren't liked by your immediate supervisor, then expect to be targeted. Your coworkers can be the absolute nicest and absolutely love you, but your immediate boss can absolutely dislike you. It feels like a massive popularity contest.  Opportunities for advancement are impossible to come by if you're not liked. Those that break the rules are overlooked, yet if you're doing your job (and aren't gossiping like others) you'll get in trouble for it.  Management will make the work environment toxic so that they can force those that they don't like out , by restricting your opportunities, targeting you, and then retaliating after reporting them to HR...Which in the end doesn't solve any thing.   Supervisors will actually force you into a situation where you have to choose between getting your education and keeping your job...there is no workaround.

review_title: Don't let their core values fool you, they will work you to death!
pros:
- Decent amount of PTO
- Benefits are decent (not great, but comparable to other organizations nowadays)
- Great break rooms, good coffee/tea
cons:
- Work/Life Balance is a joke!  Long hours expected, even weekends and it is very hard to take PTO
- Morale in the EPMO among the Project Managers is really low.
- Lots of "its not my job" type attitudes
- Management are too busy vying for position to listen to their employees
- Seems like some in power know they can't be fired and do what they want regardless the company's core values (or that is how it seems)
- Their processes are broken and they seem to think creating more is better than fixing what they have.  This leads to confusion and frustration.

review_title: St. Joseph and Highline Medical Centers
pros: I have worked at St. Joseph's for most of my career but I recently started working at Highline.  I will say that we have a great deal of talented, compassionate staff-members at both campuses.  Many managers do a great job and rally for their department.
cons:
Franciscan has recently acquired a lot of new hospitals. It is great we are growing, but there are still a lot of hiccups with the acquisition and roll over of culture and standards into a new hospital that had previously had their own way of managing themselves. 

Also, CHI benefits don't cover birth control for their workers if the intended use is only contraception.  I think this is morally unethical. This was at least the case when I was an FTE, and because of Trump's new actions nullifying the requirement that employers must offer contraception in their medical plans, they will definitely revert back to this.

review_title: Good benefits even for part time!
pros: Even as a part time employee I was given loads of paid vacation and ample sick days. This is where management is very understanding. I was treated as an adult should be and given these when requested (given that I proved enough notice ahead of time which is the responsible thing to do anyways).
cons: The department I worked in they where not very flexible with my hours. And being a full-time student as well they refused to work around my school schedule so I had to leave.

review_title: Too many cooks in the kitchen spoils the pot
pros: Great co workers, pay & benefits, flexible time available, great direct management and local management.
cons: Too many levels of leaders trying to make local decisions at a national level. Local leadership and staff had to jump through too many hoops to get to their end goal - patient care & outcomes! Outsourcing seemed to have gotten company in trouble and issues continued to be handed off to other business sectors without true resolution. MUCH talent was lost with all the layoffs, leaving workloads on those who remained, decreasing morale, patient care, and patient safety. Knee-jerk decisions seemed to be a huge downfall.

review_title: Executive Assistant - Find another place to work!!!
pros: Only 2 pros: 1) Good PTO policy 2) great coworkers
cons:
CHI is hemorrhaging money.  They don't know how to control their expenses - "mostly penny wise & pound foolish" !  

They espouse core values based on the Catholic faith but they do not implement them.  They talk the talk but fail to walk the walk!

Their highest level executives are in ivory towers and do not know or care what the staff thinks or feels.  

They select Vice Presidents without considering or vetting their people skills.  Thus, they have VP's in positions where they do not develop rapport with their direct reports nor do they keep the lines of communication open.    I would say they are at the least insincere and at the worst - deceitful.

review_title: Should be known as Corporate Healrh
pros: Good pay, benefits are nice.
cons: Management takes advantage of employees. No longer Catholic & charity oriented but focused on profits for executives who receive their quarterly bonuses on the backs of the employees who work their tails off but recieve no help or direction from supervisors or managers. Directors continue to lie to staff, if you are not an RN or MD you will be used up and discarded. Worked here for almost 10 years, the last 2 were hell under insufficient management, short handed staff and general incompetence, not to mention the dishonesty & focus on profits over staff & patients. Joe Wilczek is no longer the CEO and it shows.

pros: All I can think is PTO, although last year we were required to take a week off between Christmas and New Years. All holidays also come out of your PTO.
cons:
Lay offs not due to performance but monetary only. So those that deserve to stay were let go. Really was a popularity contest. 
 One team had half the team members laid off and keep management so the ratio for manager to employee is 1:1. 
EPMO  does not follow the rest of the company in allowing work the ability to work from home.  A PM mentioned in another review the VP does not believe in it so most managers do not allow it. 
Issues with Clarity and QA

pros: I don't have a lot of pros. I wouldn't ask a friend to work here even with a $10,000 sign on bonus.
cons: Once again, we are red headed stepchildren. We are treated like factory workers without names or faces, a dime a dozen. Never enough nurses. Unsafe patient to nurse ratios.

pros: A good group of people.  When times are good, they can provide a good stable place to work.  When times are thin... CHI will cut positions and work at below normal levels but the work continues....  Relaxed atmosphere in some hospitals but not in the Denver Office!
cons: Very good gig to be in Sr. Leadership here.  If you are middle management , Analyst or everyday worker you will feel your place.  Sr. Leadership really bought into the Affordable Care Act and it cost the average worker and their benefits greatly!  Politically correct atmosphere where your speech is controlled. No words like bullet points, execute, on target..."these are "violent" terms.  Stiff environment in Denver.  False friendliness is very common.

pros:
An interesting mix of patients
Benefits
Some wonderful, positive people work there!
cons:
Negative, passive-aggressive culture in some areas
General unwillingness to change/accept different ideas by leadership and many of the original Bergan staff
Supervisors and management unable/unwilling to address real issues yet like to micromanage petty concerns, propagating drama.
Too many managers under the director leads to all knowing some info but none knowing all
Director claims an open-door policy yet maintains a closed-minded, "my way or the highway" approach to employees.  Do not question management.
If you find yourself on the director's bad side, your work-life will be made miserable.
Within radiology, of the 4 core values of CHI, only Excellence is pushed by management.  Reverence, Integrity, and Compassion are not the focus and were not shown to me, especially in the past year.  Money and doing more with less has become the main focus.
Mid and upper management do not see the on-going struggle with short staff.

review_title: St. Clare hospital promises a lot to employees, but delivers too little.
pros: Team-oriented staff. Several high quality physicians with whom to work. Encourage certification in nursing specialty. Committed to community. Great volunteer program. Recognition programs.
cons: Novice executive staff and managers. CHRONIC understaffing, sometimes at dangerous levels. Excessive turnover and high proportion of novice staff with limited mentoring. Excessive management turnover. Little to no professional development. Excessive spending on consultants. Culture of fear and retaliation if staff disagrees with management decision. Significant favoritism. Ivory tower mentality of management. Thinks too much in the short term at the expense of long term improvement. Insufficient communication.

review_title: Not bad but not very good either
pros: CHI provides countless interesting opportunities for learning and development.  A lot of very nice and friendly people. Pay and benefits are good compared to other companies. Fairly laid back environment although one may encounter sensitive individuals here and there.
cons: Management is quite authoritarian when it comes to decision making. Has some unrealistic expectations. It almost feels like they aren't in touch with the reality. Countless useless meeting where people go on and on with their discussion only to end up nowhere. Some people tend to complicate stuff beyond belief which leads to inability to make decisions.

review_title: Not good--if you are not a Pendleton native, you are treated like an outsider from the cliques of natives.
pros: Senior management appears to be trying  to make the atmosphere better by implementing some systems to discourage nurses from treating each other poorly.  The nurses have a union that represents us, so pay and benefits are prevailing wages.
cons: It's much like high school- the "popular-- e.g. Pendleton natives and old-timers"  treat the "outcasts--e.g. non-natives" very coldly.  It's not outright hositility but you feel it with the actions on a daily basis.  I know another employee that was a "non-native" that didn't work in nursing but another allied health field and she was treated the same way, couldn't take it and quit.  I'm ready to go as well.

pros:
Professional environment with strong cooperation amongst most cross functional teams.
Good pay and benefits, comfortable environment with high cube walls filtering out distractions.
Nice facility in a pleasant area of town - access to gym and showers in building.
cons:
Leadership does not appear to understand IT and does not have IT representation at the C-level.
Quick growth of Member Organizations without required update to infrastructure to support such growth.  Some in-fighting amongst management groups bleeds over into disruptive environment for members requiring cross-functional team cooperation.
As a Not-For-Profit, political climate in DC appears to have direct impact on funding, drastic layoffs occurred within last 6 month cycle.

review_title: CHI St. Joseph Primary Care 29th Clinic
job_title: Patient Access Representative in Bryan, TX
pros: There are no pros to working here. You will be stressed...overworked, understaffed, etc. everyday. The management is inexperienced, largely absent, and disconnected from staff. The only good thing is there is a great team of nurses there who support each other.
cons: Overworked, underpaid, understaffed, lack of clear roles/duties. ABSENT and inexperienced management that avoids confrontation until it's too late then tries to use scare tactics which doesn't work. The work volume is overwhelming as the clinic is overscheduled for the amount of providers and staff. There is NEVER a moment of silence. The phones will ring non-stop all day (9 lines), there will always be a line of patients waiting in the front.

review_title: Controlled chaos at an organization that gives them takes away.
job_title: Senior Analyst, IT Asset Management in Denver, CO
pros: Good healthcare benefits, decent vacation time, great people to work with, nice facilities that includes an onsite fitness center, and free covered parking.
cons: Lagging technology, outsourced IT services with multiple vendor partners that makes accomplishing tasks extremely challenging, and so much work it can be difficult to utilize paid time off. Additionally, the company provides ways for employees to earn healthcare incentive dollars in a health savings account, but takes those dollars away from employees who leave the company, even after those dollars have been earned by actions taken by the employees while employed at the company, thereby wasting employees time and tarnishing the image of the organization.

pros: The people at the operational level are wonderful to work with. Most are very cooperative and work with you to solve problems.
cons:
Processes and procedures are not always clear when initially implemented therefore making it difficult to perform duties at a high level and come up with process improvement. Most process is handled at a high level having most operational resources left out to follow and have no say in how to improve the process even though they work it on a daily basis.

There are no clear career paths, minimal promotions, you have to be looking to apply for new positions if you want career advancement.

pros: Wonderful colleagues. Epic ok. Overall stable but management too top heavy
cons: 1) greedy management, 2) unappreciated medical staff,3) un collegial working environment,4)too many meetings and non clinical demands,5) very cheap and won't pay according to existing market,6) hospitalist are the lowest of the totem pole. Nurses have more power and they complain a lot. Admin listens to nurses more than doctors. Just no respect.7) too much cross coverage

pros:
Large, national company
A focus on in-sourcing support departments (except for IT)
cons:
Rapid growth and change has created many challenges
Too many strategic directions (CHI National, Local MBO) competing with each other.
Management makes decisions based almost solely on the bottom line and on the ability to document a "savings".
IT support is abysmal due to outsourcing. Patient care is often affected and IT issues are not resolved in an effective/prompt manner. No IT accountability.

pros: Many locations to work at, fast paced and rewarding.
cons: Management is very detached from the employees and since they are trimming the fat of some of the management it is becoming worse.  Under performing staff, supervisors and directors get same benefits and raises as high performing staff.  They like to move schedules around frequently without notice to employees or hearing the employee concerns about the changes. No flexibility in weekend time off if it is "your weekend to work".

pros: Our group was great to work with.  We always helped each other and exchanged ideas and knowledge.  Pay and Vacation is adequate compared to other companies. I truly loved working with the people at CHI.
cons: Upper management had no idea what we were doing.  Outsourcing fragmented the company greatly and made it hard to get anything done.  Resolution of issues were tremendously delayed and impacted Patient Care.  A lot of analysis and process paralysis....

job_title: Preoperative Support Specialist in Golden, CO
pros: Direct patient interaction and the ability for people wanting to explore medicine to see all of the poop and rewards that come with it.
cons: Although the job is consistent it can be mundane cleaning work and if you are not a long-range thinker then mistakes can be made easily because of the routine work. Although be warned that there isn't much advancement in this field unless you have a RN degree.

review_title: It was a good experience to work at S.V.I.
job_title: Monitor Technician in Little Rock, AR
pros: I felt like I was part of a close circle of professionals, and a second family. Also loved the opportunity to work additional shifts from sick call ins. I was fortunate to have reg scheduled hours packed close together and would complete my assigned shifts on weekends/ wkend nights.  PRN shifts during weekdays.
cons: Working night shift lessens the opportunity to speak with superiors, and departmental directors. Difficult to gain accomadations for regular compliancy needs for my schedule, as night shift.  All events were centered around days.

pros:
I feel like I was on the only team that was worthwhile.

I received quite a bit of useful training.
cons: Every other team enjoys the perks of sitting in meetings all-day, and not actually accomplishing any work. There are a bunch of tenured people sitting in positions, that may be well over their heads. Many people in middle-management and above really don't have a clue over the areas they are over, and are unable to keep up with the meetings their managers and directors have them going to, that they force the "worker bees" to attend meetings in their place. There ends up being everyone is always in meetings, and very little work is actually getting done.

job_title: Applications Analyst II in Lexington-Fayette, KY
pros: Fantastic working environment, mostly solid team members with little drama and strong skillsets. I lucked out and had a great salary. They did the best they could to help everyone transition during layoffs and outsourcing. The severance packages were excellent.
cons: Significant lack of stability during a two year long reorganization effort, every application IT team was outsourced. Massive layoffs in IT as well. Not everyone on a team that was outsourced was offered permanent positions.

review_title: Very deceiving place, I strongly recommend everyone to not accept an offer from you guys,
pros: Laid back environment with friendly co-workers.
cons: I was hired in September 2015 as an SQL developer. Not sure why I was hired because thats not my background at all. In last week of November, we were told that there is a giant lay off coming up (laid off 1,500+ employees). 1st week of December, I was laid off. RIGHT BEFORE CHRISTMAS HOLIDAYS! That's not the CHI I signed up for. Upon hire, I was told on how much CHI cares for its employees, not true at all! The ethics of CHI, managers don't follow that at all. I strongly recommend everyone to not accept an offer from you guys,

job_title: Senior Financial Analyst in Englewood, CO
pros: Nice building, nice location, I learned a lot about healthcare and the ACA while working there, and recently saw the VP I worked for laid off with a 2 year severance after being an employee for less than 2 yeas, (pro for him)
cons:
Acquisition of unprofitable MBOs, back stabbing manager told me "You're one of the most technically competent people I've ever worked with, but you have a problem with managing perception".  I went from an "exceeds expectations" to having my goals rewritten prior to my review to exclude most of what I'd been working on and completed for the year.  Then I was "laid off", but they tried to deny unemployment.  (unsuccessfully)  Trustworthy, Loyal? Fail.  

Working for CHI was the biggest mistake of my career.  "Cronyistic capitalism in the guise of a faith based not for profit" from another review aptly describes this snake pit.

pros:
Night shift has excellent team work and look out for each other. decent chance of getting your requested time off, but that goes for any floor in the hospital (based on seniority).
Benefits are good for the area, but milticare (Who i now work for) are better, as well as better pay.
cons:
Day shift: cattie, selfish and bullies. Won't even do their work until a couple hours in when managers arrive. And they get a way with yelling at their coworkers. 
Evening shift need retraining, patience complained about the lack of skill, nothing gets done.
Management: will block you from transferring even though you have perfect attendance and excellent yearly reviews. And that includes when you finally finish school. 
Rumors going around that they are giving the coveted spots (Mother-Baby Unit) to external applicants over internal candidates.

pros: Fairly busy level I trauma hospital that sees a high acuity patient population. Beautiful hospital. Hardworking staff.
cons: Administration, leadership and executive leadership is in a constant state of flux. Budget, profit, and patient satisfaction is the name of the game. Staff satisfaction, retention, and input are not. Nursing turnover is a huge problem and entry level management must toe the line, or its on to the next one. My job satisfaction was little to none during my tenure there. I continue to talk to current employees years later, and things have only gotten worse. I would not work for this company again.

pros: Coworkers are amazing and onsite payroll deducted daycare is unbeatable. Many locations to choose from in the metro area lending to many different facilities and transfer options.
cons: Pay is the lowest in the city and has been for quite some time. The benefits are expensive and cover very little, even when you stay in network. The organization overall has adopted an idea that " a nurse is a nurse is a nurse" philosophy. We are often floated to areas of the hospital into specialties that differ vastly from our own. They have implemented an inter hospital float pool that hired NEW GRADUATES to float to acute care floors including ICU. Since the acquisition of Alegent Creighton Health, CHI has fostered an environment based on greed and substandard care.

review_title: Acknowledge the bad, and adjust/ Reward the good, showcase individuals talents & projects.
job_title: Cardiac Monitor Technician in Little Rock, AR
pros: Definitely has historical and honorable heritage. I loved being able to innocently appreciate the origin of early mission when St.Vincent Infirmity was beginning.  Very proud & honest work.
cons: The procedural administrative procedures were followed, but seemed like any negative or any sanction ever granted attention from administrations.  Like a "demerit for" not adhering to policy but very rare mention or rewarding notability for good leadership or personally involved for good cause.

job_title: Registered Nurse in College Station, TX
pros: Some of the floors had good culture, and the pay is pretty on par with what you'd expect. Benefits and PTO were decent. There are good nurses and staff there, and if you can find them you'll have a much better experience.
cons:
Management in general is a joke, especially on the telemetry floor. Every floor has its own problem, it definitely has a "pick your poison" feel sometimes.

Also, if you want to change units for whatever reason, you're better off quitting and reapplying instead of asking for a transfer. They will block you from leaving, and the unit you interveiw with will tell your current unit.

pros: Quality of life isn't bad, most departments offer flexible work schedules, pay is decent for Denver market
cons: Politics are awful-you only get promoted if you play the system, not based on work product, in fact the less effective you are, the better.  Lots of people in positions they shouldn't have, some employees are borderline illiterate and because of the flex work schedule a lot of people don't even bother showing up to work, even as VPs and up.  Benefits are only given to those that don't deserve them. The "Catholic" title is just a title.

review_title: Great organization riddled with typical non-profit/healthcare politics and inefficiencies
pros: Great mission and values based organization. They really cared about people and most were trying to do the right thing.
cons: Senior Management seemed incapable of making tough decisions and delegating. Some people in roles they were not qualified for and in their uncomfortable inadequacy would got on the offensive to deflect from their inability to be effective. The National IT organization was culturally not representative of the greater organization.

review_title: Disorganized and dysfunctional team, other teams were good
job_title: Applications Analyst II in Denver, CO
pros:
Good starting pay
idea of company is a great one - centralized corporate support to several small / medium / large sized hospitals around the country
Working for a non-profit private health care system that serves a mission
cons:
it took over 2 months to get a laptop
management was extremely disorganized
People are people everywhere you go, and CHI is no exception. There were teams that were painfully unproductive and dysfunctional, the leadership was continuously in flux. Other teams were stronger, with more stable leadership. Be careful which team you are interviewing for, there is such a wide variance of leadership.

pros: Great coworkers and unit manager!
cons: Promises that were made when our hospital was purchased have not been kept. This company is all about money and giving the best to physicians but does not care about the patient, the family, or its nursing corp. There is little opportunity for advancement. Chief Nursing Officer would rather give us excuses and not help solve problems. Pay is very low, and they are cutting our hours. I used to love my job, I have given almost 10 years to this hospital, but will be looking for another position at another hospital,

review_title: Maturing Organization; Need to Align with Current Leadership
pros: Good organization that is doing work work. Opportunities to advance if you land in the right part of the organization and with a leader that is strongly aligned and who likes you. Maybe this is true in every organization.
cons: Industry pressures and corporate culture is oriented toward how well you are aligned with some of the new (past 3 years or so) leaders. Like all organizations there are  sacred cows and people. Leadership gives the impression they want honest and collaborative feedback but unfortunately that was not my experience.

review_title: The past six months have been horrible.  Poor leadership, frequent changes in direction, staffing cuts and general chaos
pros: Took position because of their Mission.  They used to truly live it.  Salary and comps are good.  Used to be a family type atmosphere.
cons: Managers are expected to work 24/7 if need be to get all that is on their plates accomplished.  Managers are burned out, stressed out and over worked.  Budget cuts have left departments without enough staff to safely care for patients.  Serious concerns that quality health care is no longer being delivered.

pros: There is a great team environment, collaboration, and a willingness to help.  From leadership to nurses on the floor, to the behind the scenes service staff, everyone cares about the patients.  This is a place where I would go for health care.
cons: Sometimes it seems as though CHI Franciscan and the national leadership are not on the same page.  There are some disconnects between the local staff and national staff.

pros: Telecommuting available.  Still receiving a paycheck until I find something else.
cons: Very Poor Executive and Senior level leadership across ALL of national.  They are focused on the dollar in their pocket and nothing else.  Lost site of values and mission a few years ago (forgot our ultimate goal is patient care and wellness)  These same national leaders do not follow the very processes and policies we are required to retrain and agree to annually, as well as, they are often in violation of compliance and demonstrate unethical behaviors, but are not held accountable. Every employee is just a number, sitting on a perch waiting for their tap on the shoulder.

review_title: The founding sisters would be horrified!
pros: Benefits are good. Love the faith based values. There are some really great people here.
cons: Always short handed. Employees are always leaving for better opportunities.  New hires are making more than some of the people that have been here 10+ years.  Management preaches core values, but do not actually practice those values.  HR is here as support for management, not the employees.  Employees are afraid to say what is really going on around here for fear of being fired.

job_title: RN Wound Care Coordinator in Tacoma, WA
pros: Decent pay, my work has no weekends cause I work in a clinic.  It is hard for me to find anything good about this company. It is a struggle.
cons: Always low census. Does not support education. You have to pay out of pocket first before they reimburse.  We do not have enough hours.  Manager has favoritism

review_title: Overworked and underpaid on high acuity psych unit.
job_title: Behavioral Service Tech in Omaha, NE
pros: You can switch shifts with coworkers to help with a more flexible schedule in their rigid 7a-3p, 3p-11p or 11p-7a shifts. Some staff is able to work 3 12's.
cons: Management staff-reduces shifts to help with revenue and leave RNs/techs on this high acuity psych unit always understaffed. Very stressful position.

pros: You cannot say faith based organization because nobody follows this anymore. People roll eyes in regards to reflections. As soon as I find another job I will be leaving.
cons:
Negativity throughout employees
Upper management will not do anything to keep good employees
No room for growth even if they say there are. You would have to jump teams and that risky now with the constant layoffs since 2011 and since we are trying to dig ourselves out of a 2.5 Billion dollar hole. 
Will not fire the bad ones but lay off good ones. 
We call ourselves faith based but that is ridiculous with all the backstabbing that happens
Low ball wages always counter in a big way
Too many upper management employees 
Too few workers for the jobs 
Stressful environment
Benefits keep disappearing not competitive with other companies

pros: CHI is a very stable healthcare company.  They have a set of core values that is difficult to maintain across a $10B company but you can see the effort is there
cons: Recent constraints in the healthcare market are forcing CHI to outsource some of their IT functions.  This is jeopardizing some of the hard work they have done moving from a holding company to an operating company over the past 8 years.

review_title: Love the people I work with; that's IT!
pros: The clinical staff (CNA, RN, PT/OT, LCSW, MD...all of them), open to new grad's, endless supply of overtime.
cons:
Management & executive staff care about NOBODY!  Pt safety is often compromised by staffing shortages and inexperienced staff (hence, VERY HIGH turnvoer coupled with tendency to ONLY hire new grads).  If you report problems, you WILL BE retaliated against.  Population can be particularly challenging.

Some are hopeful with new CEO while the few old-timers believe the changes they've waited years for will never come.

review_title: Was on of the unexpected lay-offs but would go back in a heartbeat
pros:
Work life balance is very valued. Sure at times you work over 40 but for the most part it is not much over 40. 
Insurance is excellent and they always give you chances to lower even more 
PTO is good 
I really enjoyed the people.
cons:
They made us take mandatory PTO last December 
Lay-offs never fun for anyone and more coming.

pros:
Work / Life Balance
Corporate core values are very appealing
Corporate HQ in convenient location at south end of DTC
Talented and dedicated staff-level employees
cons:
Frequent failures to live up to core values
You pretty much need to know somebody to get hired into a management position
Health benefits not as good as you'd expect working for a healthcare company 
Financial struggles: layoffs, extreme cost-cutting, etc.

review_title: All downhill since being taken over by CHI
pros: I bring home an average paycheck
cons: No longer about patient care and all about the money. Very poor management and zero appreciation for hard working staff. Always short staffed and told everyday "Dr.s need to get their numbers up" (more patient visits) All about quantity and not quality of care. Internal issues take forever to get addressed if addressed at all, etc IT issues, dealing with HR, poor computer training. Poor communication between depts. and between management/staff. I could go on forever.

pros: Great teamwork with staff- other Nurses, CNA's, HUC's, most Dr's readily available.
cons: management plays favorites, targets you if they want you gone. Everyone can be doing the same thing, yet only you get in trouble for it. Managers sit in offices and won't help when the floor is in crisis. Dangerous place to be if you are a patient. Need to closely look at the pt you are picking up to see what might have been missed or screwed up on the shift previous to yours.

review_title: Your Job directly relates to Helping People be Healthy!
pros: Great coworkers who are team players. Good benefits. The Mission aligns with our desire to help people and do good in our communities.
cons: Top Management constantly changes things due to Merger/Acquisition activity. Little job security due to continual reorganization/lay-offs. Problems with IT sometimes make work difficult.

pros: Good people and good work life balance. Not many vacation days but they allow certain employees to work from home.
cons: Terrible pay, terrible advancement opportunities.  Also not very advanced in terms of the systems they use, which translates to not much experience value when looking for other jobs. I thought leaving here that I had a good grasp on Excel - got to my next job and realized soon that I had a ton to learn to catch up.

job_title: Pharmacy Intern in Little Rock, AR
pros: I mostly worked every other weekend in the clean room. The schedule was very accommodating to me as a pharmacy student. There were opportunities to work more hours in the pharmacy or help with a monthly clean. Management and coworkers were great. The pay was good and there was a weekend premium. I stayed very busy during the weekends I worked so the shifts went by fast.
cons: None really. It was a good part-time job for me as a pharmacy student. There was no down time to study so if that's what you're looking for then I would reconsider.

job_title: Applications Systems Analyst in Englewood, CO
pros:
-Lots of opportunity, as CHI IT is continually reinventing itself. 
-CHI will never run out of work to do. 
-There are offices in several cities, plus they allow some remote employees.
cons:
-The CHI IT department was reorganized multiple times in my 3 years there.  There was never a org chart; it was continually fluid. I was on the Epic team and I reported to three different supervisors within my first 5 months
-The teams are continually understaffed.

review_title: Great place to get introductory RN experience
pros: Working as a registered nurse on 7 north was like working with family.  Most everyone is very easy going and friendly.  When I started as a new nurse, I never felt scared to ask a question if I didn't know something. In this field of work, questions are encouraged.
cons: Short staffed on some weekends.  Meaning possibly taking 5 (rarely 6) patients (where the standard is 4:1) on a med/tele floor during day shift. Tennessee does not have minimum ratio laws

pros:
-Remote work opportunities 
- Great benefits
cons:
Layoffs, layoffs, layoffs!
Employee morale
Financial driven leadership not leading by the core balues

pros: Flexible, option to part-time telecommute, the appeal of working for a faith-based company.
cons: It doesn't seem anyone actually follows through with being a faith-based company, you find politics and hidden agendas are constantly an issue.  Layoffs have happened every year for the past 4 years, the company thinks they need to ramp up new hires and then end up laying off people.  Layoffs 2 weeks before Christmas in 2015 were a really classy move.

review_title: A company with lots of potential but too many egos and people in the wrong jobs!
job_title: Project Manager I in Englewood, CO
pros: The group of PM's I worked with were experienced and took great pride in their jobs and the experience they delivered to their customers. Office culture is OK, not a lot of flexibility as far as remote work, as people in positions (at VP level) don't agree with it, even though the department outgrew multiple work locations and there were hiring/pay increase freezes.
cons: Peanut butter approach to raises except at high levels; meaning that everyone if they are decent will get the bare minimum, which is usually 3-5%. This doesn't promote people who are at the bottom to try harder and people at the top to consistently hold up their level of customer service. It says, no one is any different and regardless of how much you work, how much time and effort you put into your job, you will never be differentiated or paid anything more than than the average worker year over year, as far as raises are concerned. It is socialism.

review_title: Don't work for CHI. The healthcare market is hot, leave while you can.
pros: Some select amazing and highly skilled colleagues. Sadly, I don't think they will be able to make a difference and their skills will be wasted.
cons: Human resources abuses power manipulating management to support their own political agendas. Management's opinions and 'facts' change with the way the wind blows to protect their own jobs. Leadership is the poorest I have ever seen; incredibly disingenuous and passive aggressive. The culture is a cross between being in a 'cult' and being back in high school. While the rhetoric is innovation and progress, it is all lip services. The protective instinct is to squeeze out progress to maintain status quo.

pros: Good people and a few good leaders... hardworking colleges trying to remain patient and sane....just hoping for some positive change soon.
cons:
I'm truly saddened and embarrassed about the quality of work our department has deemed as acceptable. 

This department has lost organization, structure, and accountability since the replacement of our last director. Countless processes are being missed, neglected, or possibly ignored on purpose to protect the false perception of "meeting sla." 

We don't have department meetings anymore and team to team communication is a constant struggle. Leadership now only meets every other week...How can you expect to work out these issues with one hour meetings every two weeks?

Stop tip toeing and actually pin point the problems. Leadership needs to find an open and honest dialogue with each other and needs to be more transparent with each team. Make some changes, try new things, make mistakes.. but doing the bare minimum and letting things slip is really taking its toll on the employees working for this department. 

For the past few years It feels like leadership is always blaming the lack of progress on "the waiting game."  Waiting for new and "better" systems to solve all their problems. Unfortunately the sloppy choices and poor implementations only cause more issues and frustration for the employees having to adjust.

pros: Friendly patient care staff. Would've left 3 years ago if they weren't so great!! You are the only thing that keeps that place going!
cons: Management is horrible. Middle management does whatever they want without being held accountable for anything. Staff not given tools needed to meet goals. Staff is blamed for dissatisfaction of patients even though it's because the building is in bad shape, nurses are chronically understaffed, and the equipment either doesn't work or is non-existent. Management won't let people transfer even if they're miserable because staffing is so bad. They'll find a reason not to let you go just because they can.

job_title: Sr. Biomed Technician in Omaha, NE
pros: Family environment, flexible PTO, decent technology.  Decent pay for nursing and direct care providers only.  Easy access to local upper management depending on location.
cons: Don't let them know you are in the military if you want to be hired or move up. Salaries are low and performance raises are averaged and regardless of your evaluation you will receive the same raise as consistently low performers.

pros: I work with good people.  They finally wised up and fired the Chief Information Officer and the next in line who were destroying the culture with their enormous egos.    It has been getting better since then.
cons: There is generally no career path in Information Technology.  I am nearing retirement so that is not a problem for me.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Hoffman Estates, IL
pros: Immediate supervisors and middle-management / directors are very hands on when dealing with associates. There is an open door policy that allows for open and transparent communication. Supervisors and middle-management seem to genuinely care about their associates.
cons: With a rapidly changing healthcare environment, upper management, hospital administration do not seem to be as concerned with front line employees as they used to be.

review_title: Company was dishonest about what job they were hiring me for; then blamed me
job_title: Direct Care Worker in Fargo, ND
pros: They have a computer system that access the patient's every need and progress.
cons: When they hired me I agreed to work with a patients with 2-3 physical disabilities. They did not disclose his severe mental illnesses so I ended up not being prepared, and then discovered he was very abusive. I would never have accepted this job if I knew the facts as I was emotionally abused in childhood and cannot deal with that type of patient. They then would not switch me to another patient, saying the patient was who they hired me for, so I had to end my employment with them.

review_title: Mercy Medical Center CHI Hospital in Williston, ND
pros: Lots of variety in clinical challenges
cons: Standard of care appears to be centered right at mediocre and anyone exceeding that level of care is summarily driven away by the incompetent or uncaring long standing providers. There is very little concern for the well being of patients.  During my tenure there were over a dozen very good physicians who left after abuse from the old timers.  The hospital leadership sees nothing wrong with a physician b wing abusive to nurses, humiliating them, blaming them for his errors, hurting patients, and in general being a disruptive force within  the organization. Nurses are not respected and are not recognized for their efforts.

pros: Lakeside had a great mix of patient diagnoses and also a broad mix of socioeconomic backgrounds.  They have hospitalists and the majority of patients transfer their care to the hospitalists during their inpatient stay.  I was able to work closely with occupational therapy and speech-language pathology which contributed to a neat team approach.
cons: Productivity was a huge emphasis.  Frequently it was overemphasized, especially because quality can easily take a 'back seat' as a result.

review_title: Great in 2008 but in 2013 horrible treatment of its employees and HR doesn't care.
pros: In 2008 things were good. Management cared, understood and respected its employees.
cons: NO respect for its employees. Supervisors have bad attitudes ALL the time. Use HR as a way to shield themselves and persecute its employees. Management DOES NOT know the jobs they direct and/or supervise, play favorites, and clearly show its an all boys club.

pros: Core values are RICE: Reverence, Integrity, Compassion, Excellence. These are part of the culture across most levels of the organization. They are working hard to position the organization for the future of health - care and reimbursement. Multiple locations across the country. Have a "workable" remote worker policy. Highly values and respects diversity in both their employees and patient populations.
cons: Highest level management communicates openly and with appearances of honesty and full disclosure but some senior executives are clearly not competent and they remain with the organization. Senior management does not always practice their core values.

pros: Pay is good, benefits are above average, nice offices and location (if you live south of Denver).
cons: CHI is so far from their stated values that it's become a joke.  There is nothing faith-based about this place, except for the name.  No concern for employees, leadership has no idea what they are doing and change direction monthly.  There is no stability here, layoffs at least every 3 months.  Absolutely no transparency here, leadership will lie right to employees faces in "town halls" and "employee forums".  My advice to anyone looking for a job is stay as far from this place as possible, it's a real mess!

pros: Highly rated 5 star Hospital in Chattanooga Tennessee. Great Heart program in which I have worked for the last 9 years and have enjoyed the company of many great patients and worked with excellent staff.
cons: Difficulty of having staffing at times in CVICU but they have always done their best even-though there has been a shortage of bedside nurses who work well with sick patients and have the experience needed to excel in that field

pros: I honestly cannot think of any, other than talented employees whose potential aren’t being utilized due to fear of middle management.
cons: Middle management is highly incompetent. Plays favoritism and uses fear mentality; and if you voice your concern, well, you might as well place a target on your forehead. Middle management does pretty much what it wants. The (acting) Director is useless in his role. He is a puppet and whichever the wind blows he follows. Who is going to hold middle management accountable???!!!

review_title: Can be a good place with strong manager
pros: Great benefits, core values.  CHI has lots going on in I.T. so it feels very secure.
cons: HR is, in a word, peculiar.  There are strange rules about salary increases and promotions.  Any type of HR process takes an incredible amount of time -- getting hired, being promoted, applying for and moving to a new position, etc.

review_title: Horrible.  CHI is on a mission to self-destruct
pros: They have a pension, good PTO
cons:
They bombard you with their 'core values' of reverence, integrity, compassion and excellence and they practice none of those things.
The pay is nothing, we're constantly getting emails telling us that if we don't do this or that it's another thing that will cause us to not get a raise.
They're eliminating positions (which they fail to realize are staffed by real people) and reducing hours because of 'the budget'.  They're one of the most financially sound companies I've ever worked for but they will cut your throat to save twenty cents.  Our CEO even stated at a meeting that we're making money, just not as much as we did before.  Instead of being thankful and counting their blessings in rough economic times, they're throwing people out on the street or reducing the hours of the lowest paid employees (those who need them the most).
Morale is in the toilet.
I have never (not even in junior high) seen so much gossiping, back stabbing, conniving, lying and vitriol.  The staff go after each other like a pack of starving wolves.
They put everyone through numerous 'patient safety' training courses but refuse to staff enough nurses.  Although the training courses are good, they're useless - patient safety is compromised by overloading and overworking nurses and no amount of training courses will protect patients from a staff stretched too thin - it's only a matter of time before something catastrophic happens.
Management actively refuses to improve morale and become noticeably agitated when employees offer suggestions.  Members of my department were recently told that if they're not happy, they can quit.
I never thought I would see this as a negative, but...they promote from within (to a fault).  The people at the top have been there for 30 years and they do things today the way things were done 30 years ago.  There are no new ideas, no one to bring experience and innovation with them from other organizations and running a hospital in 2013 with a 1980's mentality is a recipe for disaster.
It's a shame that CHI has forced its hospitals into money machines - this place used to be like a family and was filled with caring, compassionate people.  Today, it's a shark tank.

*I said the business outlook in the next 6 months would be getting better only because they will do whatever it takes to make money - the culture and disregard for employee and patient safety will not improve (until a court orders CHI to change or they replace the CEO and other senior management)

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Des Moines, IA
pros: PTO, Insurance , Adequate time off. Co-workers are easy to work with.
cons: Right hand doesn't know what the left is doing. Faith based organization what a joke, just a facade to hide behind. All about money. Would rather bring in travelers than pay an incentive to part time to fill gaps. Patient care not what it used to be, just want warm bodies don't care about experience.  People are scared to voice concerns because then you get a bulls eye on your back. Yearly surveys that don't mean a thing other than who answered the questions honestly, not what they wanted to hear. Very political.

review_title: Epic analyst team thrown out like garbage

The first reductions over Christmas of 1500, then just recently the whole Epic team in three locations, thrown to the street. Poor benefits, pay below scale. Religion based but not followed.

review_title: Leadership completely out of touch at the APSC
pros: Hourly employees are fantastic, eager to provide suggestions for improvement, and great teamwork
cons: I have worked for CHI for over 5 years.  When I started working here, I genuinely felt that the core values were important, and were practiced.  Over the course of the past few years, they have become a joke.  Most of the downturn on morale has been due to the interim director.  The term leadership is not appropriate, rather she is a dictator that refuses to listen to the many suggestions of employees, or see any fault in herself.  She does not understand the day to day operations at the ground level.  It has been suggested several times that she spend a day with the hourly employees to obtain more of a grasp of the task they complete, and the time it takes to do so, with no avail.  She has also implemented an unrealistic attendance policy, which results in termination after four call ins, regardless of  if the notification is provided the day prior.  This is extremely insensitive and lacking in compassion for the employees, as many of us have families, and ongoing medical issues.  Furthermore, managers who's mistakes are corrected on a daily basis by hourly employees are being considered for promotions, due to a high-school-like clique mentality of the current director, while the hard working managers that actually want to make changes for improvement have been passed over time and time again.  This has lead to employees feeling very defeated , and does not foster motivation
