review_title: Inspired work family delivering exceptional care
job_title: Senior Recruiter in Little Rock, AR
pros: I have worked for CHI St Vincent for 18 years. I can't imaging working any where else. Our leadership team is engaged, visible, and provides endless support to the co-workers at CHI St Vincent. We have incredible growth opportunities through scholarships, tuition reimbursement, certification incentive, career ladders, and promotional opportunities. Beyond all of that, we are called to action each day to provide the best possible care that we can to our communities and one another.
cons: Healthcare, in general, is very hard work. I do not, however, see this as isolated for CHI St Vincent. I believe this to be true of all Healthcare facilities.

review_title: The ability for PM's to manage their projects as they sit fit is limited - too many processes, templates, rules!
pros:
- Flexible work environment that allows us to balance personal/work life
- Input into the types of projects we manage
- Great group of people in EPMO and for the most part across the company
cons:
Benefits:
Benefits are self-funded and the worst I have had - seems like an oxymoron when you work for a health care company! The Catholic beliefs trickle down to the benefits (they won't pay for ANY form of birth control; yet plenty of non-Catholic employees - so it is forcing their beliefs on their employees. That doesn't seem to demonstrate the diversity of their workforce. Benefits are very person, individual and they should be managed with those needs in mind.  Moved to co-insurance which Leadership tried to sell as better than co-payments, I do not see this as the truth. I am paying approximately 25% more now. 

Compensation:
I hear you will never get more than 5% to move from one job to the next - confirmed by other PM's and groups within the organization.  No rhyme or reason as to why someone gets hired as a PM1 vs PM3. They will not publish their pay ranges, so you never really know what you are going to get and how to move to the next level. Because the company doesn't pay as well as others, you would think there would be some other benefits to offset that, which leads me into the telecommute policy.

Telecommute policies:
CHI has a policy, however, because the VP of the organization doesn't believe in telecommuting, he felt it necessary to develop his own policy (which has taken over a year to implement). Some groups are allowed 1 day a week, while others only 2 days a month. Other groups within CHI can work remotely up to 2-3 days a week. In addition, this is so micromanaged is ridiculous! VP micromanages his direct reports and has instructed them to monitor everyone so we cannot have the same work from home day every week, even if one day works better than others. What happened to treating people like adults? If you don't trust your management/staff - get rid of them and replace them with people you do trust. Let them do their jobs and manage the organization and projects, rather than worrying about who is working from home when. The most interesting thing is that the EPMO hires people that don't work anywhere near a CHI facility - they work from home 100% of the time.  We have also had full-time resources that lived in CO move out of state and are permitted to work from home 100% of the time. Double standards across the board! 

Management of company resources:
The company has lost a ton of money, the IT resources and dollars have been poorly allocated and managed and yet we continue to acquire more space for employees. BRILLIANT IDEA ALERT - move to a cube share and quit acquiring space. This is not rocket science! Be responsible, move into the 21st century and build tools that allow you to better manage your resources so you can let go of the fear of telecommuting. Quit hiring expensive firms to come in and tell you how to do things. You can take that money and better invest elsewhere. Hold more ALL company meetings to learn what is happening in the MBOs so that we quit doing duplicate work.  HOLD PEOPLE ACCOUNTABLE! I know of plenty of dead-weight, we are paying good money to people who accomplish nothing, do not follow-up and manage their projects or complete their tasks.

Process and templates
Some process and templates are helpful. What CHI has is overkill. The PM's do not have the ability to manage their projects as needed - we have to use this template, that template and they have also required us to use an interface between MS Project and Clarity (the PMIS) and it doens't work and you have to take a two hour class just to figure out how to use it - why not just let us manage our projects! We spend more time in training and then taking refresher training and going to meetings that we cannot effectively manage our projects.

job_title: Registered Nurse in Federal Way, WA
pros: Diversity is strong and work culture is great among my fellow team of nurses, at least in the specific area that I work in. Great place to start out if you're a newer nurse, but definitely assess your own needs and expectations if you're a more experienced nurse (you may find a better deal, with better resources, working some where else).
cons: I have worked for St. Francis in Federal Way for over 5 years now and was hired during an interesting time when there was quite a bit of turn over due to nurses retiring or seeking other opportunities. I think this is the case for most facilities. I think they handled this in the best way they could, but nurse staffing shortages were common. Year after year there seemed to be more turn overs, even with newer nurses that had completed their residencies. Most of the time this was because they sought higher education or similar opportunities. More experienced nurses (5 plus years of experience in some cases) would leave for better benefits and pay, which is not very competitive for the area, especially compared to the rise in the Seattle market. There is rarely incentive to stay- there are no bonuses and no benefits to being a long term employee (except that you get a better set schedule, which was the case for me). St. Francis is considered a stepping stone for most incoming nurses who are coming in as new-grads seeking a residency.  I'm not sure if this is something new or not, but I feel that recognition, retention, and overall appreciation for employees has fallen to one of the bottom-most priorities. I think this definitely harming morale and creating negative  feelings towards management. I think that supporting experienced staff members should actually be a priority, especially in how high the acuity has grown for this particular facility. It would make sense that they would funnel a little more resources into supporting their nurses if they have active plans to grow (which CHI has demonstrated with its mergers and expansion plans, which includes St. Francis as well).

review_title: Great opportunities in the past, but lots of changes, especially in IT
pros: There used to be a lot of great people, and the managers were great about letting people cross-train and learn new disciplines. I have been able to move around and get into different areas. I have learned a lot.
cons: The CHI merger has been difficult on the staff, and a lot of people have walked away, or have been pushed into more silo'd roles. There seems to be a big effort from CHI to outsource a lot of the ongoing support of systems and people are left wondering if there are jobs waiting for them after things shake out.

pros: If you're a hard worker report to work everyday and strive to be the best, this company will recognize you and will advance you.  Managers take care of their employees they offer flexible schedules, manageable work loads. the company is constantly looking for ways to improve relations and make working for the company fun and enjoyable. the company has many different locations but the 2 locations that I have worked for even has a fun committee set up to encourage fun by setting up department parties and luncheons.
cons: Division between other departments can be felt, not by managers but in passing in the halls

pros: The company offerED excellent salary, family type environment. Great room to advance. The work was challenging, rewarding, and fun.

After being ridiculed by a senior VP, we found out all tech services was getting outsourced to a US based company, which was actually based in Bangalore, INDIA. Not to competent, pleasant, skilled, or intelligent foreigners, but to completely the opposite. The money they expected to save by firing all of us, should have been re-invested in us, to make the company better off than what it was.

pros: None, really. Often referred by the disgruntled as a cess pool.
cons: Call offs were often times not noted on call off sheet and the aide or nurse ended up being fired for being a no call, no show. You will be told you are making enough.  New people with no training will make more than someone who has been there several years, but may have ten years prior experience. pros:
Good pay for my job type

review_title: CHI is a challenging yet rewarding place to work.
pros: Great pay and benefits. We start each meeting with a reflection, poem or quote. I have never worked at a faith based organization and really appreciate the focus on mindfulness in the workplace. Good work/life balance.
cons: There's some uncertainty regarding a possible merger, but that could also mean more opportunities for me!! review_title: Wish I hadn't left for what I thought were greener pastures.
pros: I worked in a small department out of the Service Center and it was an extremely supportive environment. Coworkers stepped up and helped out their fellow workers when there were family tragedies and management rewarded their staff frequently for a job well done.  The management and Executive leadership truly embodied the values of Reverance, Compassion, Integrity and Excellence.  Annual Thanksgiving, Christmas, Oktoberfest, family picnic and other holidays were celebrated with sit down meals for all staff at all locations or platters of cookies, fruit and veggies.  75% tuition reimbursement including books was a great help on finishing my degree as well as several scholarships each year awarded to staff or family by the Foundation was another perk of working there.  Involvement and fundraising for community non-profits was supported and encouraged as well as Executive Leadership showing up on days off to participate in the events.  My chain of command up to the Exec listened to ideas with enthusiasm and implemented ones that were feasible allowing the employee who proposed the idea to be involved in the implementation the entire way.  If I lived closer, I would definitely be looking for a job with them again.
cons: No clear path for career advancement and salary and job titles weren't always reflective of the actual work done.  If a job review was requested to get the title and salary updated, it moved through the steps at a snail's pace and would be denied several times before a change would be made.

review_title: I think the title of the job is very indicative of the duties.
pros: I love how willing people in the department you work in are willing to help. You are not really judged if you do not know something. They are happy that you are asking if you do not understand and will make sure that it is clear.
cons: There is an extremely high amount of stress but that comes with any job in the medical field. Sometimes the departments clash due to lack of communication and that can be frustrating  if you get dragged into that.

pros: CHI Franciscan is one of the largest healthcare systems in the Pacific Northwest. It's constantly growing and creating new jobs/opportunities, and you can take advantage of that. The environment is often what you make it, so as long as you're positive/forward-thinking, work is enjoyable everyday. Management continues to look for ways to improve/streamline daily workflows, and is usually receptive to suggestions/concerns.
cons: There's very little opportunity for overtime. The education reimbursement leaves a lot to be desired. For a non-profit company, sometimes it seems like what most matters to top management is the bottom line.

review_title: We were much better off before CHI bought out St. Alexius
job_title: Certified Nursing Assistant CNA in Bismarck, ND
pros: Some of the best docs, nurses, and CNA's work here. Work hours are flexible. You can wear any kind of scrubs you want. You get to meet lots of new people every day and provide care to all kinds of patients. A fast paced environment where you get to see new things every day.
cons: Ever since we went corporate and CHI took over, the quality hasn't been as good as before. In order to "save money" they cut employee wages and laid off a bunch of people, while at the same time spending money on new computer programs and other things that weren't a priority. More people are quitting than are being hired, and they are not advertising for any job openings, even though we so desperately need more nurses and CNA's to replace the ones we've lost. Also, they take FOREVER with the hiring process; you literally have to call HR every day until you get results, otherwise they will never get back to you. Probably another sneaky thing they do to "save money."

review_title: CHI: striving to be the "employer of choice"
pros:
CHI is an organization that is values-based and faith-based with management that strives to provide an environment that respects all faiths, not just Catholic or even only Christian. I appreciate that management relentlessly pursues the achievement of values-based behaviors and standards, regardless of how hopeless it sometimes must seem. 

Employees are hired for "fit", which results in a professional environment that is positive and supportive. 

Employees are offered encouragement to advance professionally through a program that provides funding for education. For instance, a certified nurse aide can take advantage of this program to go to school to become an LPN or an RN.

Managers take periodic workshops designed to improve their management skills. All employees receive training to help them align their actions with the stated values of Reverence, Integrity, Compassion and Excellence. This is beneficial not only for their careers but also for their personal lives.
cons:
The work environment has become so fast-paced that employees find it difficult to maintain a balanced life. It's frustrating to feel that one does not have enough time or resources to do a job of which s/he can be proud.

Another problem concerns employee discipline. If one employee is having a problem following rules, whether the reason is forgetfulness, a lack of caring, or a lack of information; rather than discussing it with the employee, the department director is likely to mention the problem at a staff meeting and "remind" the entire department that it is important to follow that particular rule or procedure. The individual employee with the problem may not even realize that s/he is the one who precipitated the reminder. In similar situations, the department manager may speak privately to the employee, but if there is no improvement, there are often no consequences. This is not a consistent problem, but does happen sometimes in some departments.

Training for department leaders is not thorough, so some leaders have trouble being effective. They may avoid confronting discipline problems or they may be too heavy-handed. Some leaders are so frustrated that they seem to emit waves of negativity at times, and their subordinates feel the necessity to "walk on eggshells" and may try to avoid them altogether.

review_title: Weirdest, most efficient hiring process and workplace I have ever seen...
job_title: PFS ITS Liaison in Englewood, CO
pros:
If you are lucky enough to be in the Englewood corporate offices, they are very nice and modern with a great view.
Good coffee machine selection in large break rooms.
cons:
If you don't work in corporate office, the offices are run down, loud, and climates are often not conducive to working efficiently.

Corporate office has deemed soda as unhealthy and has removed all soda vending machines.
The culture is quite weird and people are very clique esque.

Lack of urgency on many levels (i.e. Started January 14th and still two months later did not have access to the systems in which I was hired to maintain, hence why today is my last day).

Lack of accountability from management right down to the employee level.

The organization has many missions and visions yet on a daily basis there is no evidence of living up to them.

Lack of direction from management.

Position in which I was hired for was up to 25% travel yet immediately after starting was told I would need to block the last two weeks of February, March, April, May, and June as well as August and September for travel (including weekends).

In addition to unexpected travel the organization is quite happy to reimburse you for travel expenses that you put on your own personal credit card.  Getting a corporate card was an exception and was difficult to obtain.

IT has been outsourced so something as simple as resetting a voicemail password can take up to 5 business days.

First two weeks I had a laptop but no log-in to the network and had to use my personal laptop and cell phone and email for all work functions.

Position "sold" to me during the three month interview process was nothing like what I was actually doing.

Due to poor IT management, I worked for the organization 9 weeks and did about 7 hours of work due to inability to access systems.

As the only member of my team in this office, I was expected to be here daily and just wait for IT to call me back.

If you are not part of a team on-site, no one talks to you.  As a corporate trainer for the past 6 years, I am very outgoing and introduced myself to 15 plus people around me.  That was the only time I had ever talked to them.

CHI corporate, in which I was employed with, is seen as "the bad guys" from the hospitals they have purchased across the country.  Many co-workers in other locations (i.e. Des Moines) have told me just how bad corporate is talked about and how horrible their schedules and benefits got once acquired by CHI.

Seems the company is more after quantity (both hospital systems and employees) versus quality.

No exit interview from company nor were there even questions to why I was leaving which shows a lack of respect and a lack for improvement for the organization.

CHI as a client to other healthcare vendors, the organization is seen as complicated, unaccountable, and rude at times.  While interviewing for a vendor I was almost not considered for the position because CHI was on my resume.  Upon further review they said they felt better that I was only there a short time which means I'm not crazy (this coming from an executive at a vendor in which CHI is a top client).

Promise all the advancement opportunities in the world and unlimited salary to find it was all hypothetical.

The hiring process was the most stressful and drawn own.  First phone interview (of four lasting an hour each) began at the end of September; after two video conference interviews I was later offered employent in December.

The organization uses HireRight as their background check company (check the review for that company, many complaints with the better business bureau).  The background check took 4 weeks and they called and emailed me daily asking for prove of everything.  They had the audacity to ask for my first paycheck from my employer from 2003...

My first day orientation had me meeting the HR representative I worked with, walking around my building looking at a map trying to find my cube number, and then being placed at an empty desk.  I have not seen the HR representative since then and the first two days sat at my desk waiting for an email from my manager of course using my personal email since I had no access to the CHI network.

job_title: Senior Tax Analyst in Englewood, CO
pros: Good location near Park Meadows Mall, that's all.
cons:
1. The company is not doing well overall and layoffs are a part of the norm.
2. The tax department is extremely unorganized and ran like the 1980s. The processes and procedures are inefficient and redundant.
3. The tax managers lack empathy, and for the most part, they are rude and condescending to their staff. The average tenure for a senior analyst is 6 months, maybe 7 months depending on how well you can tolerant b.s.
4. There are no bonuses for staff because of the layoffs.
5. The tax department is too cheap to invest in quality, tax tools and software.
6. Expect to submit weekly time sheets (although we are not charging clients) in order for managers to track your time. This process is inefficient and takes up more time to complete, especially during busy season.
7. Expect to not have a life from January to May 15, which is the due date for the 990 returns. You will be working a minimum of 60 hrs per week and these hours will increase each week.
8. In public accounting, you get unlimited sick days, plus 3 weeks vacation and other days off because you are working 60 hours plus during busy season. But, not at Catholic. The tax department will work you to death and you WILL NOT be compensated for it with additional time off/vacation.

Overall, the morale in the Denver tax department is very low. The managers are not supportive and there's the office gossip that you will have to deal with. Especially the manager in Kentucky, she is hell on wheels! If you are going to work 60 plus hours, you might as well just stay in public accounting and reap all of the benefits that come along with public accounting. There's no work/life balance and you can easily find better tax job opportunities in Denver that pay more money and the office environment is much better than Catholic. Again, you will be making a huge mistake and taking a risk with your career by working in the tax department.

review_title: Culture is great, liked growing with CHI
pros:
The Culture of caring is truly felt through out the company. 
There were a significant amount of growth opportunities.
Pay is far pretty much mid grade. 
They stay true to their mission of serving the poor and helping anyone.
I was proud to work there and say I did. Just a good place to work.
cons: Not anything to complain about that you won't find in any other large health care Org.

pros: A faith based, patient and community focused employer that lives the mission. Your faith is allowed to be woven into the fabric of the culture.
cons: More people need to know about how wonderful this place really is!

pros: I have experienced a lot of opportunity for growth in my career as well as support from peers. The opportunity for continued education is supported and encouraged by management and peers.
cons: Opportunities for leadership roles seem limited at times. Shared governance is in place however I do not feel that it is allowed to function as intended. This seems to be due to those in leadership roles resisting change.

pros: The company has good benefits and has a good mission.
cons: The IT function is in shambles and will continue to decline, as there is a lack of investment in people to fix core processes and operational processes.  IT leadership is missing.  Fundamental processes across finance, procurement, contracting, etc. are missing.  It is extremely challenging to get anything done given broken processes and unhappy people.  Sr. Leadership wants to outsource accountability and doesn't support its outsourcing providers.  There is constant support issues across the organization and there is only effort to figure out who to blame, instead of how to fix the problems.  Leadership refuses to fix root cause of problems and consultants are brought in to evaluate the same problems over and over... wasting money and time.  They have lost over 90% of their IT leaders in the last 2 years - this must say something. The problems are getting worse.

pros: Good working hours, Full benefits to workers at least half time. Compensation is fare but well behind the increases for inflation.
cons: Benefits continue to be trimmed, insurance companies are not based in Washington and fall under different laws that do not protect Washington Residents.  Continued expansion of services has increased business while hiring has not kept up.  Constant short staffing and scheduling of employees for overtime and time beyond there shift schedules.

review_title: Quality Improvement Coordinator - Executive Med Staff (RN)

cons: Unstable work environment for all staff. Regular lay-offs make all employees feel fear & question the leadership who implies the company is doing very well, when the quarterly numbers continue to decline. .

pros: There are some positives to working at CHI: Decent benefits; And some management, there are a couple (a very limited few) of them that seem to have the knowledge and integrity to bear the title that they hold as well as manage with an open door policy.
cons: There are many things about working at CHI that really seem to fall far below the threshold of postulation: Accountability, for one, it has been expressed to us that processes are in place to enforce accountability, be it a matter of ownership or a mere lack of triumph in required duties and responsibilities, however, I am hard pressed to witness an example of this from the majority of management; Raises, albeit appreciated, are extremely minimal compared to the amount of ever growing expectations and obligations placed before us on a daily basis; The chaotic environment, a mass of misguided direction and undedicated personnel engulf the everyday atmosphere on the third floor.

pros: None none none none none

review_title: Disappointing, lied to, not supported,back biting,unprofessional, untruthful,people fired without reason

The mid management has been there so long and is working in an old thought process that the  new tech ways are passing them by and  even though  they want change they really do not they want to stay  in the past. 
A few of their leadership team thinks they are brilliant but really need to stick with what they do best  and leave other areas to the experts,  but they cannot do this as they fire these people because they are better than they are and liked better. 
Upper leadership listens to some that whine and gloss over the real issues by not addressing and getting rid of the people that are truly there to correct  problem.
BEWARE, DO NOT TAKE A JOB THERE THEY WILL NOT GIVE YOU A FAIR CHANCE........

job_title: Manager, IT Strategic Planning in Englewood, CO
pros: Most people I work with mean well, but the organization lacks the direction and systems for employees to feel engaged and successful.
cons: The organization is run in a very reactionary manner with little to know integrated planning.  Leadership struggles to articulate a clear vision for the future and how the various national and market functions fit into that picture.  Leadership positions seem to be filled by people who have 'put in their time' rather than those are best qualified to lead the organization.  No incentive systems to align work and employee engagement.  I work with a lot of people that want to make a difference but morale is low because they feel like their expertise isn't valued and they aren't clear on where they should be focusing their energy.  There are some very clear tools that could be used to improve alignment and engagement across the organization but even when some one steps up to make a difference they can't get senior leadership support to truly embed the change.  They are just left on an island until they give up and fall in with the status quo or leave the organization.  There were some great people with great skills and experiences when I started 3 years ago but many of them have either been laid off or left on their own.  Just not a place where people look forward to coming in because you just don't feel like you can make a difference.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Des Moines, IA
pros: Great staff and good pay for the area. Nice facility for patients. Like physicians I work with. Some ability to advance.
cons: Benefits keep changing, some benefits decreased. A lot of changes in the department, politics. Parking for staff is terrible. Cafeteria food isn't great and is expensive.

pros: Their core values are amazing! I loved getting a daily prayer in my email. They implemented a group huddle/meeting every day for 10-15 minutes to go over concerns and successes.
cons: There were not many opportunities to become full-time or even part-time day hours. Working mandatory weekends and extra shifts was unpleasant.

pros: I have a good supervisor who cares about me and the people around him.  It's the only thing that makes my experience here tolerable.
cons:
You will do very well at CHI if you are a favorite of anyone in upper management.  However if you are just an average peon there is no future in sight no matter how well you perform.   
They have cut our benefits to profit themselves because the company is so financially mismanaged.  For example - HR used attempted legislation that was stopped by a federal judge effecting the status of exempt employees.  They took a group of exempt employees and made them non exempt, but failed to acknowledge that the reason they claim they had to do this was halted and thus invalid.   And  even though this group has exactly the same job description, some did not have to comply and are still exempt employees.  A blatant example of favoritism.  But there is no accountability.  By doing this, it took away vacation time from many and has caused morale problems along with all the other things that have been taken away in their lame attempt to "save a buck."  They also have shaved the severance package down to zilch.  
Morale is very poor in general in all areas I interact with across the organization.  I honestly believe they do not care.  
They say we are in a hiring freeze and yet new employees are coming in.  But many existing employees cannot even change depts. or go to other internal positions due the "hiring freeze." 
Company is in process of completing a merger so future is uncertain.  
Horrible environment for most here unless you are in the good graces of a top executive.

review_title: CHI - Worst HR & IT Departments Ever!
pros: Met some good and caring people.
cons:
Almost impossible to write up or terminate hourly employees, even with detailed time clock violations such as double digit tardies, missing punches, missing shifts and unauthorized overtime.  It also depended on the color of your skin which HR policies applied and when they apply.

The hiring process is very protracted while the operational needs are immediate.  It could take two months from start to finish to get a position approved and someone scheduled to New Employee Orientation.  While you may have as many as four employees on FMLA for months to years at a time, never really getting well.  They were never able to be counted on to be at work on any given day.  So, the rest of the staff must take on the work of several who are missing each shift.
 
If you need a temporary worker tomorrow because there really are no more employees in the HR pipeline, this process that normally takes a day at most, will take anywhere from 4-6 weeks with this incompetent HR staff.  So, this requires Managers to take on the work of correcting the errors made by overworked and understaffed associates as well as much of the actual work, instead of being able to work on what will make the department run better.

The IT department and structure is poorly managed.  Simple requests can take months to work out.  Difficult requests add many months of additional work and expense to all projects that interface with IT.  
They also outsourced their help desks to India.  Very difficult to understand the language barriers.  Usually takes several calls to get someone you can really understand and who understands you as well.

pros: Great place. New employees are usually hired not just for their skills, but based on how they fit with the team and the organization. Good pay in the Englewood, CO offices with better than average benefits and a favorable work-life balance in most  departments.
cons: Catholic Health Initiatives is struggling financially. There have been a number of RIFs in the past year.

pros:
Sense of Family.
Endless Teamwork.
Devotion to the mission and community.
Enhanced sense of pride you feel when you go home each day.
cons: Government Regulations and the continuous reimbursement changes in the Healthcare market, leaves the organization in a constant state of re-organization to manage expenses.

review_title: CHI was not a good place to work at all

Corporate takes over these small hospitals and runs them from Denver with no regard for any local needs.  Most of the hospitals CHI manages would be much better off if they were on their own.

pros: The people are really nice.  The culture is respectful.  People feel like they are contributing to something important.  Benefits are solid.

job_title: Human Resources Payroll in Florence, KY
pros: This is great to build your resume to go into a human resources field. People think that it looks great to work here
cons: You are not taught the processes. You are taught how to expect other people to do your job for you

job_title: Talent Acquisition Specialist in Omaha, NE
pros:
+ In the central office - in human resources you do have the ability to work from home.

+ Fair wage (unless you have student loans or are trying to go back to school. The continuing education reward isn't enough to cover a part time attendee. And the loan forgiveness is only for clinical staff - they will ask for that money back if you don't complete the terms of service)

+ Work/Life balance just okay

+Monthly metric bonuses for recruiters (The only position to allow that. And when you're in the position you are not allowed to communicate that fact to any other employee or department)
cons:
- Lack of opportunity to grow within the company. Usually 5 - 7 years before promotion or growth.

- Massive layoffs in HR this past year. Department went from 200 to 100 with 50 of those working through the national office in Denver

- Snake environment. They were taking recommendations in open meetings about which positions to cut. 

- Leadership would purposefully put people on probation around the end of year performance reviews so certain staff members weren't eligible for raise to meet FY budget. (This happened both years I was with the organization) 

-Management would encourage staff to give good reviews of the organization even when cutting staff, salaries, etc.. 

- Lack of trust in the community. Whether it was a poor patient review. janitorial services not getting paid, or physicians leaving because of the hostile environment. 

- Every department is secluded from each other (Mktg, HR, Finance, etc..) Very siloed out to prevent sharing of ideas and or information that leadership doesn't want going through organization. 

- All of Leadership has accepted end of year bonuses even when it comes to massive lay-offs. (This has happened every year since 2014.)

- Not a young office by any means, they fear millennial ideas and leadership. Often times in a clinical setting they have supervisors who stay way past retirement and this creates an atmosphere where young clinical staff don't want to stay. 

-They have almost a 25% turnover rate which is higher than the industry average of 14%. 

- They often lose shining millennial  talent throughout the organization because of lack of growth and salary flexibility 

- In laying off positions throughout the organization they often times don't back-fill those positions but just merge the duties with current employee roles in order to save money. This creates a backlog of work that is often days and sometimes weeks long. (If you have trouble reaching the central office on the phone, that is why.) 

- On-site food/ cafe is poorly run and the food is overpriced and very mediocre

- They preach health and fitness to the office but the majority of staff are overweight, over worked, stressed, and disrespected.

- Social media / marketing plan tries to reach out to community from an ivory tower and avoids grassroots campaigns similar to UNMC, Madonna, and Methodists

review_title: Short term employment to learn and move on is the best approach here.

review_title: Not a Nice Place to Work
pros: The people in my department are wonderful, experienced and hard-working and dedicated.
cons: CHI bought our hospital in 2013.  Since then ALL of our previous upper management staff have either "retired" or were fired and replaced with CHI executives. They do not value their employees.  They took away seniority of staff who had worked at the facility for many years. Their benefits are horrible.  Health insurance co-payments are so high that I cannot afford to see my doctor let alone get a blood draw  or have any type of procedure.  They put our department on a hiring freeze, and refuse to allow us to hire clinical staff to care for patients.  Our department has been forced to send referrals to other area hospitals because of lack of clinical staff.  CHI is billions of dollars in debt, and yet they are turning away patients and closing departments constantly.  There is a lot of outsourcing of jobs and departments. Their pay is very low.  There is no job security for anyone except upper managerial staff.  The employees do not trust upper management.  Department managers don't even trust upper management.  They continue to buy up more and more hospitals, but refuse to support the ones they currently own.  Financials speak for themselves.  The outlook for the hospitals that they have recently bought are grim.
